questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the vulva?
questions.explanation: The cervix is not a part of the vulva, it is a part of the uterus.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding labia majora?

options.A: They join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure
options.B: It is homologous to the scrotum in males
options.C: The round ligament terminates at its posterior end
options.D: It contains sebaceous glands and apocrine glands

questions.explanation: The round ligament terminates at the anterior end of the labia majora. The labia majora lie on either side of the vulva and join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure. The inner side is hairless. Labia majora are homologous to the scrotum in males. The labia majora and the mons veneris contain: hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and modified sweat glands, known as apocrine glands. The labia minora are two cutaneous folds between the labia majora. Anteriorly they enclose the clitoris and unite with each other in front and behind the clitoris to form the prepuce and frenulum respectively. The labia minora are homologous to the ventral aspect of the penis. The clitoris is a small erectile body lying in the anterior-most part of the vulva. The clitoris is homologous to the glans penis.

questions.question: A patient presented to the gynecology OPD with the following finding. Which structure in men is homologous to the affected structure?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a Bartholin's cyst, which involves the Bartholin's glands. These glands are homologous to the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of Bartholin's glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o'clock positions. They are stimulated by sexual arousal. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions. Bartholin's cyst occurs due to obstruction of the ducts of the Bartholin's glands by proteinaceous material, or due to infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision. An infected Bartholin's cyst can lead to a Bartholin's abscess. This requires surgical drainage.

questions.question: What is the pH of the vagina before puberty?
questions.explanation: The pH of the vagina before puberty is 7. In adult females, the pH is acidic. Doderlein's bacilli (Lactobacillus sp.) are part of the normal vaginal flora. They produce lactic acid from glycogen in the vaginal epithelium and make the vaginal pH acidic. They are present in newborns and disappear in 10-14 days. They reappear at puberty and disappear after menopause. Vaginal flora also includes microbes such as Clostridium welchii. Vaginal defense mechanisms are influenced by estrogen. In newborns, maternal estrogens maintain the defense mechanisms for 10-14 days. After that, the levels wane. During puberty, the circulating estrogen maintains the defense mechanism. Note: The pH is higher in the upper part of the vagina due to mixing with alkaline cervical mucus. Period: Birth-2 weeks, Vaginal pH: 4-5, Doderlein bacteria: +2 weeks-puberty >7, Types of cells: Parabasal cells. At puberty: 4-4.5, Reproductive, 4-5, sparse/plenty, Superficial & intermediate. During pregnancy: 3.8-4.1, plenty. Postmenopause: >7, Intermediate/Parabasal cells.

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect about relations of the vagina?
questions.explanation: Bartholin's gland is present lateral to the vagina. The vagina is related to the following structures: • Anteriorly: • Bladder (upper 1/3rd) • Urethra (lower 2/3rd) • Posteriorly • Pouch of Douglas • Ampulla of the rectum • Perineal body • Laterally • Mackenrodt's ligament • Levator ani • Bartholin's glands. Anterior and posterior relations of vagina: Cavity uterus, Cervix, Uterovesical pouch, Peritoneum, Rectouterine pouch - Rectum, Bladder, Urogenital diaphragm, Anococcygeal body, Anal canal, Urethra, Vagina - Rectovaginal Fascia, Perineal body. Lateral relations of the Vagina: Bulbospongiosus, Transverse cervical ligament, Levator ani, Pubovaginalis.

questions.question: Identify the type of hymen.
questions.explanation: The given image shows a cribriform hymen because it has multiple small openings. Based on the shape of its opening, the hymen may be classified as: Other variants of the hymen. The hymen is lined by stratified squamous epithelium on both sides. The hymen is most commonly torn posterolaterally or posteriorly. It is replaced by tags after childbirth, which are called carunculae myrtiformes.

questions.question: A patient with uterine prolapse and urethrocele has weakness in the superficial and deeper perineal muscles. What level of support is lost here?
questions.explanation: In the given case scenario, level 3 supports, including the superficial and deep perineal muscles, are lost. This causes urethrocele. DeLancey's levels of support are used to describe the supports of the genital organs.

questions.question: Anteflexion of the uterus is at the level of
questions.explanation: Anteflexion of the uterus is seen at the level of the internal os. (Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina) The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion. In the anteverted position, the external os is directed downward and backwards. On vaginal examination, the fingers come in contact with the anterior lip of the cervix as it is the lowest part. When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix becomes either the external os or its posterior lip. Angle of Anteversion: The angle between the cervix and vagina is 90 degrees. Angle of Anteflexion: The angle between the cervix and uterus is 120 degrees. Anteversion and anteflexion of the uterus: Axis of uterine body, Axis of vagina, Axis of cervix, Angle of anteversion, Angle of anteflexion. Normal uterus - anteverted, anteflexed. Retroverted and retroflexed uterus (usually occur together).

questions.question: A G3P2L2 woman presents in her third trimester with vaginal leaking. On PV examination, the anterior lip of the cervix can be palpated. What is the position of her uterus and the ligament that maintains this position?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the uterus is anteverted as the anterior lip of the cervix was palpable. The round ligament helps maintain the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy. However, the anteversion in the non-pregnant uterus is maintained by both the uterosacral ligament and round ligament. (Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina) The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion. In the anteverted position, the external os is directed downward and backwards. On vaginal examination, the fingers come in contact with the anterior lip of the cervix as it is the lowest part. When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix becomes either the external os or its posterior lip. Anteflexion is seen at the level of the internal os.

questions.question: A multiparous woman presented with a urethrocele, due to weakness of the urogenital diaphragm. What is this structure also known as?
questions.explanation: The urogenital diaphragm is also known as the triangular ligament. The urogenital diaphragm extends from the pubic arch anteriorly to the central point of the perineum posteriorly and consists of two layers of fascia through which pass the vagina and the urethra. The central point of the female perineum lies between the vagina and the rectum. Urogenital triangle: Present between 2 ischiopubic rami. Stretching transversely across the rami, there are 3 membranes. From above downwards, the membranes are as follows: Superior fascia of urogenital diaphragm, Inferior fascia of urogenital diaphragm, and the membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia. Perineum - urogenital and anal triangles: Ischiocavernosus, Bulbispongiosus, Transverse perinei muscle, Levator ani, Gluteus maximus. Urogenital triangle: Vagina, Perineal membrane, Ischial tuberosity, Sacrotuberous ligament, Anus, Anal triangle.

questions.question: What is the cavity of the uterus lined by?

options.A: Single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium
options.B: Double layer of ciliated columnar epithelium
options.C: Single layer of ciliated cuboidal epithelium
options.D: Double layer of ciliated cuboidal epithelium

questions.explanation:
The uterine cavity is lined by a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. The wall of the uterus consists of 3 layers: 
   • Perimetrium is the serous coat adherent to the underlying muscle. 
   • Myometrium - it consists of thick bundles of muscles that form 3 distinct layers during pregnancy: 
   • Outer longitudinal 
   • Inner circular 
   • Middle interlacing called living ligature 
   • Endometrium - It is the mucous lining of the cavity. It consists of lamina propria and surface epithelium which is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium.

questions.question: A woman with regular menstrual cycles is undergoing an ultrasound on the 14th day of her cycle. What will the endometrial thickness be?
questions.explanation: During ovulation, the thickness of the endometrium is around 11 mm. Phase Endometrial thickness Immediately after menstruation 1-2 mm, Early proliferative phase 5-7 mm, Secretory phase 7-16 mm. Phase Endometrial thickness Preovulatory phase up to 11 mm, Postmenopausal <4 mm, Postmenopausal - abnormal, requires biopsy >4 mm

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding uterine anatomy?

options.A: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery
options.B: Transverse cervical ligaments are also called cardinal ligaments
options.C: Uterine innervation is by the pudendal nerve plexus
options.D: Lymphatic drainage is primarily to the obturator, internal and external iliac nodes.

questions.explanation: The uterus is innervated by the fibers of the uterovaginal plexus, also known as the Frankenhauser ganglion. Option A: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery, which represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery. Option B: The cardinal ligaments are also called transverse cervical ligaments or Mackenrodt ligaments. They consist primarily of perivascular connective tissue. They attach to the posterolateral pelvic walls near the origin of the internal iliac artery and surround the vessels supplying the uterus and vagina. Option D: Lymphatic drainage of the uterus is primarily to the obturator and internal and external iliac nodes. One theory of endometriosis states lymphatic spread as a cause for seeding in the pelvis.

questions.question: A gynecologist is performing a hysterectomy. She accidentally nicks the ureter in the ureteric canal as it pierces the Mackenrodt's ligaments. Which vessels are likely to be damaged here?

options.A: Uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below
options.B: Uterine plexus of veins above and the uterine artery below
options.C: Ovarian artery above and the uterine artery below
options.D: Uterine artery above and the ovarian artery below

questions.explanation: The uterine artery above and uterine venous plexus below are likely to be damaged here, as the ureter is present between these vessels. The ureter pierces the Mackenrodt's ligament, forming the ureteric canal. In this canal, the ureter is crossed by the uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below, thus being present between the uterine vessels. The ureteric canal provides the necessary room for normal peristalsis, without pressure from the surrounding structures. After leaving the ureteric canal, the ureter passes forwards and medially to reach the bladder. It is 1-2 cm away from the cervix.

questions.question: You take a culture swab from the portio vaginalis of a woman having foul-smelling vaginal discharge. What is this region also known as?
questions.explanation: Portio vaginalis or exocervix is the other name for the vaginal part of the cervix. Cervix is the lowermost part of the uterus extending from the histological internal os to the external os. It is cylindrical in shape, measuring 2.5 cm in length and diameter. Cervix is made up of 10% muscle and the rest is collagen, elastin, and proteoglycan. The lining of the cervix has the following parts: • Exocervix - also known as portio vaginalis. It is lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. • Endocervix - it is lined by high columnar, ciliated epithelium. • Endocervical glands secrete alkaline mucus. When enlarged, they form swellings called Nabothian follicles/cysts. • Transformation zone - the epithelium gradually changes from columnar to squamous in this region.

questions.question: What is the cervix: corpus ratio before puberty?
questions.explanation: The cervix:corpus ratio before puberty is 2:1. The relationship between the length of the cervix and that of the body of the uterus varies with age. Before puberty, the cervix/corpus ratio is 2:1. At puberty, it is 1:2. At 24 years of age, the reproductive age, the ratio is 1:2. After menopause, the cervix/corpus ratio is 1:3 or 1:4-2:1; however, the uterus and cervix are both atrophied.

questions.question: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in
questions.explanation: The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the Wolffian ducts in women. These are located in the broad ligament and the vagina. The Gartner's duct is an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. It runs parallel to, but below, the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus to the level of the internal os, where it passes into the tissues of the cervix. It then runs forwards to reach the anterolateral aspect of the vaginal wall and may reach as far down as the hymen. The duct can sometimes form a cyst in the broad ligament or in the vagina. It is called Gartner's cyst. It is a benign condition and can be treated with marsupialization. Embryology of Female reproductive organs: Abdominal ostium of uterine tube, Mesonephric tubules, MSinus tubercle, Remnants of mesonephric tubules, Cortical cords of ovary, Mesonephric duct, Uterine canal, Epoophoron, Paroophoron, Menovarium, Corpus uteri, Remnant of mesonephric Gartner cyst, Cervix, Fornix, Upper part of vagina, duct.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the contents of the broad ligament?

options.A: Ovarian vessels in its infundibulopelvic part
options.C: Ureter is present in the lower portion
options.D: Ovarian ligament in its anterior fold

questions.explanation: The ovarian ligaments are contained in the posterior fold of the broad ligament. The broad ligament contains the following parts: • Mesosalpinx - it lies between the fallopian tube and ovarian ligament. It contains the pelvic vessels - anastomoses between uterine and ovarian arteries. The ovary is attached via ovarian ligament through the posterior folds to the mesovarium. • Mesometrium - it contains the ovarian vessels within the infundibulopelvic ligament. The ureter is present in the inferomedial part of the broad ligament. It is related to the uterine artery here and may be damaged during hysterectomy. Note: The broad ligament is not a support of the uterus.

questions.question: Where are peg cells seen?
questions.explanation: Peg cells are seen in the fallopian tubes. A peg cell is a non-ciliated epithelial cell within the fallopian tube. These cells are also known as intercalated or intercalary cells, whose function is not yet known. The image below shows pale ciliated cells (arrows) and narrow, dark, non-ciliated peg cells (arrowheads). Secretory cell, Ciliated cell, Peg cell, Stroma, Muscle

questions.question: What is the longest part of the fallopian tube?
questions.explanation: The longest and widest part of the fallopian tube is the ampulla.

questions.question: Where is the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary derived from?
questions.explanation: Tunica albuginea of the adult ovary is derived from the subepithelial connective tissue layer. Structure of the ovary: • Surface epithelium - a single layer of cuboidal cells is present, which later gives rise to the surface epithelium of the adult ovary. It is morphologically continuous with the mesothelium of the peritoneum. • The subepithelial connective tissue layer - gives rise to the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary and the basement membrane beneath the surface epithelium. • The parenchymatous zone - becomes the cortex and contains the egg nests and ovarian follicles. • Zona vasculosa - becomes the medulla and contains the blood vessels. Hilar cells present here are homologous to interstitial cells of testes. They can rarely produce hilar cell tumors of the ovary. Corpus albicans, primordial follicles, ovarian ligament, corpus luteum, structure of the ovary, hilum with blood vessels, tunica albuginea, primary follicle, medulla, cortex, Graafian follicle, ovum.

questions.question: During the histopathological examination of an ovarian mass, Call-Exner bodies are seen. In which of the following layers are these structures seen?
questions.explanation: Call-Exner bodies are formed by granulosa cells present within the granulosa cell layer of the ovary. They are small, distinctive, gland-like structures filled with acidophilic material, resembling immature follicles. They are characteristically seen in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary. The image below shows Call-Exner bodies (circled in black). Graafian follicle: The mature Graafian follicle is spheroidal or ovoid in shape. It contains pent-up secretion known as the liquor folliculi. The lining consists of: • Theca externa • Theca interna - contain the theca cells • Granulosa cell layer • Cumulus oophorus - projection of granulosa cells into the cavity of the Graafian follicle. It is also called the discus proligerus. Theca externa Theca interna Basement membrane Granulosa layer Antrum Cumulus oophorus Corona radiata Zona pellucida Perivitelline space. Oocyte Hillock

questions.question: Where is the sympathetic nerve supply of the ovary derived from?
questions.explanation: The efferent preganglionic sympathetic fibres to the ovary are derived from the T10-T11 spinal levels. These fibres travel to the prevertebral ganglia, where they synapse. The postganglionic sympathetic fibres arising from these ganglia contribute to the ovarian plexus, which innervates the ovary. The ovarian plexus is a network of nerves comprising: postganglionic sympathetic fibres, preganglionic parasympathetic fibres from the sacral outflow (S2-S4), and visceral afferent fibres (responsible for transmitting sensory signals). The ovarian plexus has two parts based on its connections: the upper part, derived from branches of the renal plexus and aortic plexus, and the lower part, derived from the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses.

questions.question: Bleeding during normal menstruation occurs due to rupture of
questions.explanation: Rupture of the spiral arteries causes bleeding during normal menstruation. This is a branch of the uterine artery. The blood supply of the uterus is as follows: Uterine artery → Arcuate artery → Radial artery → Basal artery → Spiral artery. Uterine artery - branches within the uterus: Ovarian artery, Arcuate artery, Radial artery, Basal artery, Spiral artery. Endometrium, Myometrium

questions.question: A uterine artery embolization is being planned for a patient with uterine fibroids. Blood flow in which of the following arteries will not be affected by this procedure?
questions.explanation: In the given case scenario, blood flow in the vaginal artery will not be affected, as it is not a branch of the uterine artery. The vaginal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery. It is homologous to the inferior vesical artery in males. It supplies the vagina and the base of the bladder in women. It should not be confused with vaginal branches of the uterine artery. Branches of the uterine artery: • Ureteric branch • Vaginal branches (descending) - these unite to form the anterior and posterior azygos arteries of the vagina • Circular cervical branch • Sampson's artery - it runs under the round ligament. It represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery. • Arcuate -> Radial -> Basal -> Spiral and straight arterioles of the functional layer of the endometrium. Aorta. Arterial supply of uterus and ovary. Suspensory ligament - Fallopian tube. Common iliac artery. Ovary. Ovarian artery. Spiral arteries. Uterine artery. Vaginal artery. Internal iliac artery. Arcuate artery. Mesosalpinx. Radial arteries. Uterine artery - Branches within the uterus. Ovarian artery. Uterine artery. Arcuate artery. Radial artery. Basal artery. Spiral artery. Endometrium. Myometrium.

questions.question: A patient with stress incontinence required surgical management. While performing a Burch colposuspension, the surgeon approached the space of Retzius. What is this space also known as?
questions.explanation: The space of Retzius is the other name for prevesical or retropubic space. Burch colposuspension is a procedure done to relieve stress urinary incontinence. If an extraperitoneal approach is selected, the retropubic space is entered by perforating the transversalis fascia layer of the anterior abdominal wall. Once the retropubic space is dissected, the bladder neck and the vaginal fascia underneath are identified. The bladder is mobilized to the opposite side. At each side of the bladder neck, two to four, preferably non-absorbable sutures are placed in the space of Retzius. Note: The presacral space is a retroperitoneal space that lies between the peritoneum of the posterior abdominal wall and the sacrum. It contains the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses. The sacral sympathetic trunk lies against the sacrum's ventral surface.
